headline: GA Peach Pound Cake
description: This Georgia peach pound cake can also be made with other fruits such as apple or cherry.

video.description: Delectable and dense pound cake loaded with juicy and sweet peach chunks.
video.name: GA Peach Pound Cake

name: GA Peach Pound Cake
recipeIngredient: 2 cups fresh peaches, pitted and chopped

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Butter a 10 inch tube pan and coat with white sugar.

In a large bowl, cream together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Add the eggs one at a time, beating well with each addition, then stir in the vanilla. Reserve 1/4 cup of flour for later, and sift together the remaining flour, baking powder and salt. Gradually stir into the creamed mixture. Use the reserved flour to coat the chopped peaches, then fold the floured peaches into the batter. Spread evenly into the prepared pan.

Bake for 60 to 70 minutes in the preheated oven, or until a toothpick inserted into the cake comes out clean. Allow cake to cool in the pan for 10 minutes, before inverting onto a wire rack to cool completely.

review.reviewBody: Great recipe! I use fresh peaches. I made a glaze. 1 cup of powdered sugar; 2 Tablespoons of water; 1/8 teaspoon of LorAnn Peach extract. Whisk and put in sandwich bag, cut small amount from corner and the drizzle.

Made this today only in mini pans. Here are my changes for next time: 1 1/2 chopped peaches and small container of Yoplait peach yogurt. With these changes my cakes should be a little lighter. I was able to make them in 6 mini loaf pans and will only use 1/8 cup of flour for the peaches. I topped my loaves with sparkling sugar before baking. Next time I will coat the pans with sugar after I spray them with cooking spray. I now call mine CO (Colorado) peach pound cakes. This is the season for our very delicious Palisade peaches.
Very moist and just right peachy. Cooked 70 minutes. Used all stated ingredients and fresh O’Henry Peaches cut in small cubes.

Baked for one hour thirty minutes and it was still not done, in texture or taste. It did come out of the Bundt pan easily. As someone else suggested I cut into slices and toasted in the oven. The taste is good but I have another peach pound cake that is 100% foolproof and taste delicious.
This cake was absolutely delicious!!!! It is easy to make, and I used real fresh picked Ga peaches!!!
Made this just to try the recipe and it was fabulous within any changes to the recipe. The cake was gone in a day because everyone loved it.

I have made this quite a few times. I don't change anything in the recipe and I don't add a glaze, although I have served it with a dollop of whipped cream or a small scoop of ice cream. It is always a big hit and is my husband's favorite cake (he is a cake fiend, so that's saying something). It is a great dessert when you are having a crowd for dinner, but I often make it for the two of us because it is so good and keeps well. I have kept leftovers in my glass covered cake plate for as long as five days and it has stayed fresh.

I get boxes and boxes of peaches given to me every year. This year as I was making THIS my favourite pound cake, I decided to put them in tiny pans for gifts. It made 5 perfect cakes! And everyone loves it. So moist and freezes beautifully. Thanks All Recipes!

I would really love to give a big thank you to whoever posted this recipe- this is the easiest dang thing ever! Baking has become my pandemic therapy - but I have never gotten anything that even remotely resembled the picture. It’s a very moist cake but the big surprise here was the crispy crust. I may have gone a little overboard draining the peaches. I always try to follow the recipe exactly and I did here except I just threw in pecans because it just seemed sacrilegious not to. I will be making this regularly!

Delicious! I tried the recipe with cherries. I used 2 cups of pitted chopped fresh cherries and the one difference was I used cake flour instead of all purpose and I did not sugar the pans. Everybody who tried it loved it. Thanks for the great recipe.

I made half the recipe & baked in a loaf pan, which turned out well.
The cake has a lovely light texture, for a pound cake. With peaches I found it to be very bland & tasteless. I hesitated making it because, altho I love peaches, they are very mild, but the reviews raved about the taste so I figured why not? 
Not….
 I will try it with other fruits offering more taste.
I’m curious to try with blueberries or lemon, pineapple or all 3 together perhaps.
Amazing!! Made with canned peaches as that’s what was available at the time. So good!

Very light ..nit as dense as traditional pound cake. Not very sweet. (Might try sprinkling peaches with a little sugar when tossing in flour)
Followed directions exactly. Next time might add cinnamon and other spices suggestions. 

 I used 2 T butter and 1/4 C sugar in bundt pan before adding batter. Maybe try a little less (but not much. Still very good)

A fabulous old fashioned flavor and texture.
I put powdered sugar over it when it was cool.
I added fresh peach purée in the glaze instead of water.
This cake smelled so intoxicating right out of the oven that I wanted to rub it all over my face. I pretty much followed the recipe…but, I added extra peaches as follows.
This is one of the best cakes I’ve ever made! Easy to make, moist and the flavor of the peaches is fantastic—Mine was gone in 24 hours with people coming back for more!
I made this just the way it's written and it was perfect to bring to a family gathering. Everyone loved the taste and texture!!
I love this cake. I was wondering if you could use cake flour to make it more moist or would that make it a mushy mess ?
Perfect recipe!
Fresh peaches made this outstanding pound cake! It’s so moist and I didn’t add or change anything! Thank you for something so delicious
Changed Peach to Strawberry, and added sugar glaze
Delicious! Made with a 15 oz can of sliced peaches; had trouble with it sticking to the pan, even still, impromptu dinner guests asked for seconds!

I’m giving this 5 stars because it’s absolutely foolproof. I didn’t have the Bundt pan so used a 9x13. No problem. I chopped up a large, drained can of peaches and folded them into the batter. Also no problem. I sprinkled sugar on the bottom of the greased pan thinking I would have a burnt mess. Nope. Came out perfectly moist and peachy with a slightly crust. Delicious!
I love the cake! I tried it with canned peaches, but it still turned out pretty well!

I love this cake. I did increase the peaches . To be honest I didn't even measure them but I used 5 good size peaches and added a little cinnamon and nutmeg to the dry ingredients. It did take longer to bake, about an extra 1o minutes but I did not decrease the temp. It turned out perfect. FYI: We live at 4000ft.

This is my go-to recipe for pound cake. Substituting raspberries works very well. In the winter when I no longer have fresh fruit in my garden, I’ve substituted slightly reconstituted dried apples and raisins (one cup each). All versions meet with approval. Note: The cake is best the day after it’s baked.

Made the recipe as it stated and it was delicious. Served it with additional diced fresh peaches and drizzled flavored balsamic vinegar over top. Highly recommend this cake as a base to many toppings! Use your imagination!

Delicious! I used 3 cups of peaches that I had sliced and covered in sugar over night. After the cake cooled I poured some of the syrup over it, topped with homemade whipped cream and a couple of sliced peaches!

This is delicious!!!! I made it as directed the first time and took to a BBQ as a dessert and everyone loved it. I made it again, cutting the recipe in half for the cake portion, in a shallow baking dish and topped with Italian prune plums and some sugar. WOW
DELICIOUS! This cake is very moist and rises beautifully even at 5,300 foot elevation.
Easy to make. I soaked my peaches in Bourbon for a week. My family loved it. I will be making it again
Twice made, second time added about 1/4 cup milk. Seemed more moist with the milk added about 10 min. cooking time.
I followed the directions exactly as written. I sliced it and put some in the freezer so we wouldn’t eat it all at once. Sooooo good. Will make again.

Delicious! I made it in a swirly Bundt pan. The butter and sugaring of the pan produced a great texture. I made the recipe as written, except I added 1/2 t of almond extract. Cooked 70 minutes. Cooled 15 minutes before inverting pan. Dusted with powdered sugar. Photo posted. Will definitely make again!

It was okay, I added almond and vanilla flavoring, the almond took over and I tasted no peach at all. It smelled of peach while I was making it, but not after. I had to bake it for about an extra 20 minutes because it wasn’t fully done in the middle. I probably wouldn’t make it again, unless I have artificial peach flavoring.

Followed the recipe exactly. Used just ripe peaches and the sweetness of the peaches gives the cake a perfect sweetness. Great with a latte. A little whipped cream on the side would make it perfect. Great recipe...
This is a great recipe. Will make again and again. A tender delicious cake. Thank you for sharing.
made this and gifted it to the therapists where i receive my p/t ; filled the center with peach slices and looked very lovely!!
Absolutely delicious! I added a home peach frosting that put it over the last top!
I halved the recipe and made it in a loaf pan. Put only 3/4 cup of sugar and it was still sweet enough! Buttery and rich enough! The coat of sugar in the pan is a nice touch!
Followed the recipes and instructions. Turned out great.

I used Splenda instead of sugar. We’ll see if anyone notices. Tastes good to me. Still dusted the pan with sugar(and flour because I did that before reading the recipe closely). Very quick and easy to put together
It was excellent! Moist, peachy and delicious.
Made as per recipe but I added a glaze made of juice from the peaches plus powdered sugar. Loved it!

This recipe was great. Made according to directions....and followed a recommendation to fold in the fruit instead of using mixer. I used fresh strawberries & cut them into 4th. Fruit blended well & has a nice light, fresh taste. Thank you.
This came out beautifully, and yummy. Cake was airtight, and later on same day, it was sooo hard! Had to dump the rest. Followed recipe. Don't know what happened.
Super yummy. I halved the recipe and made as a loaf.

So good! I made half a recipe in a 9x5 pan and baked it for 50 minutes. Perfect! Next time, I might add toasted pecans and serve it warm with caramel or Praline sauce and ice cream on top like one of my favorite restaurants that isn't around any more.

Love it, love it, love it! Didn’t change a thing and it was perfect as it is. I used margarine as that’s all my husband could get from the grocery store but even using that rather than butter this had such a buttery taste. I’ll be making this again.

Way too sweet!! Oh my... So sugary.

I made it with nectarines instead of preaches. It is very tasty with nectarines but still, so sweet. You can only eat a sliver before it is sugar overload.

Adding sugar too the buttered pan was also unnecessary.

Peaches are my favorite fruit, and this cake tastes like summer and sunshine. Sometimes t throw in some strawberries to give it a bit of a tang. Don’t add too much fruit, or you’ll have a soggy mess. I like to make mini bunds and bake them for about 35 minutes. You will love this cake.
Made it just like recipe called for it was great Will make again
Will make this again. It was easy and delicious.
Wonderful cake I have made it multiple times, it is amazing when you swap the peaches for strawberries too!

This cake is so quick to make with normal ingredients I had on hand , peaches I needed to use up and company coming for dinner. Wow! This is a keeper! So moist and flavorful! A wonderful coffee cake too!
Little Dry at 60 mins

I made the cake for guests who were coming for a multi-days visit. Served it only once. No substitutions or changes made from printed recipe, used fresh ripe peaches. I was not impressed at all with the cake...felt like a waste of ingredients and my time. Oh well...win some lose some...just don’t know unless you try it.
I followed the recipe as is and it came out very buttery and fluffy. Bake time was about 20 minutes more. This is a keeper!
This cake is yummy. It’s actually better after a day or 2

Very good, I stuck to the recipe but used cream as directed ( milk or cream) I did have to add an additional 2 T of cream for the icing. The first day it was more cake than pound cake but very yummy. Lots of compliments. Definitely will make again.
Alert, I had to put some of the batter in another pan to bake because my Bunt pan was full!
Wonderful recipe. Light, fresh taste with tree ripe peaches. Sugar ‘crust’ is tasty and fun. I made the full recipe and baked it in two loaf pans. One to eat rt away and one to freeze!

Seventy four year old farm boy who has started doing some baking.
l made this recipe today. First cake l have ever made.
Did everything correctly, except for coating the fresh peaches with flour.
I realized my mistake immediately after incorporating them in the batter.
 To late to say 
"Uh-Oh" now.
The cake turned out very well, except for being a bit too moist, caused by my old age error.
Regardless, it has a fabulous taste.
Guarantee, I'll make it again and bake it a little hotter and longer trying for a thicker crust.
 Thanks,
 Don G.
I didn’t make any changes. Shared with my co-workers who absolutely loved it!
This was a very easy cake to make and it is very delicious!
I used 2 loaf pans since I didn't have a tube pan.
I used 2 loaf pans since I didn't have a tube pan.

This peach pound cake turned out excellent and tasty too! I did make adjustments , I added a sprinkle of cinnamon after putting in peaches. Also I sprinkled cinnamon sugar to the tube pan after greasing instead of white sugar. I drizzled powdered sugar and milk glaze to finish. Will definitely make again .

We had some overripe peaches and love pound cake so I decided to try this. I will make it again. Like many others I added a teaspoon of almond extract. I also used heaping cups of diced peaches to make it really peachy. I skipped the sugar coated pan. My baking time was an hour with the oven at 350 degrees for the last 15 minutes.
Was good but it needs something. I will be working on it next time.

I made this and it was super easy, which made it even better. 
It was moist and it tasted so good I decided to make another but tweaked it a little by adding a little bourbon to the batter (maybe 2 tablespoons) and a little brown sugar to the peaches. 

Love to find a recipe I can tweak and still turns out awesome.
Really quite tasty.
tasted great with vanilla ice cream , just like peach cobbler

I followed this recipe as written with 2 exceptions: I didn’t have fresh peaches so I used a bag of frozen sliced peaches, thawed & chopped. Figured they’d be better than canned- &they were awesome. AND I measured 3 cups of flour but forgot to reserve 1/4 cup. ??????? Used a bundt pan, 60ish minutes and there it was. One of the best pound cakes I have ever made. I’m making another tomorrow just because I can! LOVE THIS RECIPE!!
Very good! I'd use more peach though :)
This was an easy pound cake. It came out delish! I added some crystallized ginger and almond extract to it for a almond ginger peach pound cake. Thanks for the recipe!
WOW! So much flavor, moist and delicious!!
I made it with 2 apples and some cinnamon and nutmeg and it turned out amazing!
Very sweet and very blend. No flavor just plain sweet. Will not try tis recipe again.
Delicious and easy pound cake! Everyone loved it as is!

I made this with fresh market peaches and followed the recipe exactly. It was delicious. My children LOVED it! I served it with vanilla ice cream and the drizzled the "Peach Sauce" from this site over both the cake and ice cream. So good.
Very moist! This is our new favorite peach recipe!

True confession. I made this twice. The first time it turned out quite heavy, dense, almost a solid pudding-like interior with a pretty cake-like exterior. I did a little research and found what probably accounted for the outcome. I had used my electric mixer on stir speed to cream the butter and sugar (I always substitute Stevia for white sugar, though I used granulated sugar to coat the floured pan, of course). The stir speed worked fine for the eggs and vanilla. So far so good; but I had kept it on constant stir speed while adding the flour mixture. Then I added the peaches. This was entirely too much stirring for the flour which I found produces a glutenous, gluey cake, precisely what mine was. Moreover, I should have taken the "fold in the peaches" direction quite literally. So this all comes from being a neophyte baker.

Second time I made it, I corrected both mistakes. I still used the mixer, which was fine. But I carefully avoided over-stirring the flour, and then folded in the peaches by hand. The batter was stiff, so the peaches had to be folded in with a large wooden spoon. The result: a wonderful pound cake. 

Maybe some other newbie will profit from my mistakes. Lesson learned.
Next time I'll add more diced peaches. Served with honey whipped cream!

I made it exactly as written with very ripe, fresh peaches (Chilton County, Alabama, not Georgia). It is delicious. It cooked 1 hour 7 minutes. It was perfect, moist inside and a nice crust on top. The batter is quite thick when you put it in the pan. I thought something might be wrong, but it was not. I will definitely make this again. Served warm with homemade vanilla or peach ice cream and it would be heaven on Earth.
I made it as written and it came out good. I made it in two loaf tins and getting them out of the pan was a bit of a challenge even though I used ample amount of grease.
Made just as written and turned out perfect! I used fresh peaches - 2 large ones was the right amount. Baked for the full 70 minutes. Thank you for sharing.
Delicious!!! Moist!
Beautiful!!! Easy recipe and very tasty. Will use this for other fruits as well.

Pretty average, one thing we noticed was that this cake literally feels like a “pound “ in your gut - not a lite dessert (and I get that it’s not shooosed to be light) but this thing seriously weighs you down...
Delicious use of fresh peaches. Adding cinnamon and nutmeg was a great addition. Good for dessert or a sweet breakfast treat.
It taste soooooo good

TWO THUMBS UP!! the batter for me was very thick, which caused it to break a not so big piece off of the cake when taking it off of the pan. other than that, the cake is AMAZING, and i highly suggest. another thing, is in the instructional video they suggested making a glaze, but i found that the cake was very sweet it’s self and didn’t really need more sweetening (which would’ve been provided by the glaze) :)
Excellent recipe .... made for the first time using fresh peaches . I should have made 2 cakes - everyone loved it. So moist and really easy to make .

Spot on old school cake! If your looking for 'a cake like Grandma used to make' , give this a try. It's very sweet, and don't skimp on butter and sugar when prepping the pan. Everyone loved this and will be a new 'old' family favorite.

Great dessert! I made this with frozen peaches in February giving us all a much needed taste of spring in the middle of a very bad winter. Have made it more than once and added blueberries once for a nice twist.

Since I am partial to almond flavoring, I added a teaspoon along with the vanilla. I used well-drained, chopped canned peaches because fresh were not in season when I first made this recipe, but can't wait to try this with fresh peaches as well. Great, festive dessert!
Great cake. used vanilla bean instead of extract and made some whipped cream to go with it.

After making this in the binder pan, I’ve decided that I would put 3 cups of diced peaches in next time. It seemed a little dry to me, but after adding extra peaches, I’m confident it will be much better. Will make it again. Also, my peaches were from our crop that we bagged and froze
